'''Karen Richardson''''s 25-year career in the [[Computer software|software]] business includes positions as a key player in several well-known and highly successful companies.
In November 2011, Richardson joined the board of directors of [[BT Group]] plc.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.btplc.com/today/art123823.html|title=Technology guru joins BT as new director|date=2011-10-19}}</ref> The company, which has operations in more than 170 countries, is one of the world's largest telecommunications services companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.btplc.com/Thegroup/Ourcompany/index.htm|title=Our company|accessdate=2011-11-02|publisher=BT Group plc}}</ref> She joined the board of Convercent, a Colorado-based provider of [[governance, risk management and compliance]] software, in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.convercent.com/about-leadership.html#karen-richardson|title=Leadership|accessdate=2013-02-08|publisher=Convercent}}</ref>
Richardson was chairwoman of the board of directors of San Francisco-based [[Hi5|Hi5 Networks Inc.]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/social_network/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=210100252&queryText=hi5|title=Social Networking Site Hi5 Nearly Doubles Monthly Visitors|publisher=InformationWeek|date=August 15, 2008}}</ref> from 2008 until December 2011, when the company was purchased by social networker [[Tagged|Tagged Inc.]]<ref name="WSJ">{{citation|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2011/12/14/tagged-acquires-facebook-competitor-hi5/|title=Tagged Acquires Facebook Competitor Hi5|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=December 14, 2011}}</ref> Hi5, a social game network with 230 million users,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.dmwmedia.com/news/2011/12/15/tagged-acquires-social-network-competitor-hi5|title=Tagged Acquires Social Network Competitor hi5|publisher=Digital Media Wire|December 15, 2011}}</ref> had once been one of the top three social networking companies, behind Facebook and MySpace.<ref name="WSJ" />
Richardson is a former adviser to [[Silver Lake Partners]], a private equity investment firm that built successful investments in Skype, Seagate Technology and Alibaba Group Holding Co. Ltd., a leading Chinese technology venture.<ref>{{citation|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2011/09/22/meet-silver-lake-the-hot-private-equity-firm-of-the-moment/?blog_id=6&post_id=34836|title=Meet Silver Lake: The Hot Private Equity Firm of the Moment|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=September 22, 2011}}</ref> She also sat on the board of i2, a Silver Lake-owned developer of investigative analysis software, until the company was sold to [[IBM]] in October 2011.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ibm-completes-i2-acquisition-to-expand-big-data-analytics-portfolio-for-smarter-cities-131133098.html|title=IBM Completes i2 Acquisition to Expand Big Data Analytics Portfolio for Smarter Cities|date=2011-10-05}}</ref> At the time of the announcement, i2 announced that 12 of the top 20 retail banks used the company's software.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/239228/ibm_acquiring_i2_for_criminal_mastermind_software.html}}</ref> She sat on the board of VirtuOz<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/virtuoz-names-eric-hahn-and-karen-richardson-to-board-of-directors-65724727.html|VirtuOz press release, 2010-02-12}}</ref> until January 2013, when the company was purchased by [[Nuance Communications]] ({{NASDAQ|NUAN}}).<ref>{{citation|url=http://techcrunch.com/2013/01/10/in-our-inbox-a-memo-that-says-nuance-has-bought-virtuoz-to-ramp-up-its-enterprise-services/|title=Confirmed: Nuance Has Bought Virtual Assistant Specialist VirtuOz To Ramp Up Its Enterprise Services|date=2013-01-10}}</ref>
Additionally, Richardson serves on the advisory boards of the Stanford Technology Ventures Program<ref>{{citation|url=http://stvp.stanford.edu/about/advisory-board.html|Stanford Technology Ventures Program Advisory Board Web site}}</ref> and the Mita Institute and Tech Accelerator (MITA), a venture capital fund that invests in Mexican and Latin American companies.<ref>{{citation|url=http://mitainstitute.com/mita-team/advisory-board/|MITA Advisory Board Web site|accessdate=February 5, 2013}}</ref> She formerly served on the advisory board of [[Proofpoint, Inc.|Proofpoint Inc.]]({{NASDAQ|PFPT}}), a provider of email security and compliance products<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.proofpoint.com/news-and-events/press-releases/pressdetail.php?PressReleaseID=56}}</ref> that went public in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/04/20/proofpoint-and-infoblox-rise-on-debuts/|title=Proofpoint and Infoblox Rise on Debuts|publisher=The New York Times|date=April 20, 2012|accessdate=April 21, 2012}}</ref>
Prior to joining Hi5, Richardson was chief executive of [[Epiphany, Inc.|E.piphany]], a developer of customer relationship management software. She also held several senior sales positions at [[Netscape|Netscape Communications]] Corp. from 1995–1998, during which time Netscape's sales grew from $80 million to over $500 million annually. As executive vice president of sales at the browser pioneer, Richardson concentrated on key vertical markets such as [[telecommunications]] and [[financial services|Financial Services]]; she also helped the company develop new markets, including e-commerce, consumer Internet access and enterprise applications. Prior to her position at Netscape, Richardson was VP of Worldwide Sales at Collabra Software, Inc., and worked for four years with [[Lotus Software|Lotus Development]] Corporation in a variety of sales and marketing roles as well as at cc:Mail and [[3Com|3Com Corporation]].
Richardson holds a BS in Industrial Engineering from [[Stanford University]] and award distinctions from the Stanford Industrial Engineering Department and the American [[Institute of Industrial Engineers]] (AIIE). She is married to [[Jon Rubinstein]], senior vice president and general manager of [[Hewlett-Packard|Hewlett-Packard Company’s]] [[Palm Inc.|Palm]] Global Business Unit and former senior vice president of [[Apple Inc.|Apple Inc.'s]] [[iPod]] division.<ref>{{cite news | last = Perry | first = Tekla | title = From Podfather to Palm's Pilot | publisher = IEEE Spectrum | date = September 2008}}</ref>
Her grandfather was a farmer from [[Saskatchewan]] who graduated with a Ph.D. in [[chemical engineering]] from Stanford; her mother entered Stanford at 16 to study [[mathematics]], and her father is also a Stanford alumnus.<ref>Educators Corner: Entrepreneurship Education Resources: A girl among geeks http://edcorner.stanford.edu/authorMaterialInfo.html?mid=1261&author=162</ref>
